instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (3.1/16gb!) Green/Orange light, no power.  Damaged <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Possibly unimportant: Came in working.  Was shutting down on login.  I thought it was OS, so wiped and reinstalled. Reinstalled fine, made user, and it shuts down when about to show desktop.  Worked fine in Safe Boot.  Weird.  Ended up buying mac from customer so she could get a new one and get back to work, and I can get a working LCD for another customer.

ANYWAY.  Finally got around to inspecting board, found water damage at <RESISTOR>R7222</RESISTOR> -> <RESISTOR>R7225</RESISTOR> (nostuff) replaced them all, checked continuity, found more damage, missing pad/trace from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> pin 22 to <CHIP>U7320</CHIP>, ran bodge after pulling chip and reworking. Was some damage under pin 22 but haven't replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> yet since EN is missing. Should I?

Now the thing doesn't power on and I hate everything :)  No good signals at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> but I do have 5VS5/3.42V/12.6V.

No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> because it's 2020

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (3.1/16gb!) Green/Orange light, no power.  Damaged <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Be sure all traces, solders and components around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> are good.
I hope you didn't solder <RESISTOR>R7225</RESISTOR>!

You must get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> before <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL>.
Actually your board seems that doesn't start at all.
I recommend to reball SMC, probably corrosion underneath affecting solder balls.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS at least?
Try to start in SMC bypass mode, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (3.1/16gb!) Green/Orange light, no power.  Damaged <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
threads.message:
Oh no! I totally soldered <RESISTOR>R7225</RESISTOR>!  Even scraped the trace and put it sideways, since the factory pad was vanished, lost to oxidation and isopropyl!  I killed it hard core didn't I? I knew to not put anything there; I know what nostuff means, but it's sure as shit soldered right there on my board.  A 0 ohm of course.

My brain went into monkey see monkey do mode maybe?! So yea, I super legit put a 0 ohm there. Good catch.  Massively good catch.  I'm impressed beyond anything, ever. Wow.

Thanks 2.  Did I kill it?  A lovely 3.1/16GB, 4924?

Edit:  I can't check 3.<SIGNAL>3_S5</SIGNAL> at this exact moment, but I do have a 32k clock which i think gets power from 3.3s5?  I can check in morning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (3.1/16gb!) Green/Orange light, no power.  Damaged <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7224</RESISTOR>/25 can NOT be placed at same time in the board.
If you did that, <RESISTOR>R7201</RESISTOR> should be burnt now.
If <RESISTOR>R7224</RESISTOR> misses from the factory, then <RESISTOR>R7225</RESISTOR> can be place; but I doubt about that, as schematic mentions NO STUFF.
